A java application I'm invoking from an Ant script in Eclipse M4 requires 
Xerces 2.2.1 in order to execute properly.  Adding an updated version of 
Xerces to J2SDK 1.4's "endorsed" directory allows this to happen. 
Unfortunately, it also breaks the Plugin editor which simply hangs when I 
click on a plugin.xml file in the Package Explorer.  

// Plugin Editor works great but my java app fails when invoked using Ant's
// <java> task
>/cygdrive/c/workspace/thirdparty/j2sdk1.4.1/jre/lib/endorsed
$ ls -l
total 2682
-rwxrwxrwx+   1 admin    None       906248 Dec  5 10:25 xalan-2.3.1.jar
-rwxrwxrwx+   1 admin    None      1730053 Dec  5 10:25 xercesImpl-2.0.0.jar
-rwxrwxrwx+   1 admin    None       108484 Dec  5 10:25 xml-apis.jar

// My java task succeeds, but the Plugin Editor is hosed
>/cygdrive/c/workspace/thirdparty/j2sdk1.4.1/jre/lib/endorsed
$ ls -l
total 2682
-rwxrwxrwx    1 admin    None       906248 Dec  5 10:25 xalan-2.3.1.jar
-rwxrwxrwx    1 admin    None      1730053 Dec  5 10:25 xercesImpl-2.0.0.jar
-rwxrwxrwx    1 admin    None       109049 Dec 10 23:37 xml-apis.jar

Note that in the above xalan.jar is 2.2.1 and xercesImpl is 2.4.1.  I've also 
tried replacing *only* the xerces jar with no better result.  Is the Plugin 
Editor really dependent on xercesImpl-2.0.0?

-----------------------------------
From Sun's FAQ:

In JDK 1.4, there is an Endorsed Standards Override Mechanism which can be 
used to override the classes in the JDK itself. To replace the classes in the 
JDK with the classes contained in a set of jar files, place the jar files in 
the $JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/endorsed/ directory. For example, to use a newer 
version of Xalan, place the newer version of xalan.jar in the endorsed 
directory of the JDK. Note, placing Xerces implementation jar files in the 
endorsed directory will also work, but it is not necessary to do so in JDK 
1.4.0.
